Among the set of options that agents choose from, the '''default option''' is the option the chooser will obtain if he or she does nothing. Broader interpretations of default options include options that are normative or suggested. Experiments and observational studies show that making an option a default increases the likelihood that it is chosen; this is called the '''default effect'''. Different causes for this effect have been discussed. Setting or changing defaults therefore has been proposed as an effective way of influencing behavior—for example, with respect to deciding whether to become an organ donor,<ref name="organ" /> giving consent to receive e-mail marketing, or choosing the level of one's retirement contributions.
== Default effect ==
=== Endogenous default effects === In a choice context, a default refers to that option which choosers end up with if they do not make an active choice. This notion is similar to the one in [[default (computer science)|computer science]] where defaults are settings or values that are automatically assigned outside of user intervention. Setting the default affects how likely people end up with an option. This is called the default effect. More precisely, it refers to changes in the probability that an agent chooses a particular option when it is set as a default as opposed to the situation where this option has not been set as default. For example, different countries have different [[Organ Donation#Legislation|rules]] on how to become an organ donor. In countries with the opt-in policy, all citizens are automatically considered as non-donors unless they actively register as donors. In countries with the opt-out policy, all citizens are automatically considered as donors unless they actively seek to be struck from the register. It has been argued that this difference in policy is the main cause of the significant difference in donor rates across the respective countries.<ref name="organ">{{Cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = E. J. | last2 = Goldstein | first2 = D. | title = MEDICINE: Do Defaults Save Lives? | doi = 10.1126/science.1091721 | journal = Science | volume = 302 | issue = 5649 | pages = 1338–1339 | year = 2003 | pmid = 14631022| pmc = }}</ref>
=== Exogenous default effects === Some default effects are implied by the situation. In social settings, for example, the normative choice (what others are doing) may be adopted unconsciously as a '''social default effect.'''<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|title = Social Defaults: Observed Choices Become Choice Defaults|url = http://jcr.oxfordjournals.org/content/41/3/746|journal = Journal of Consumer Research|date = 2014-10-01|issn = 0093-5301|pages = 746–760|volume = 41|issue = 3|doi = 10.1086/677315|language = en|first = Young Eun|last = Huh|first2 = Joachim|last2 = Vosgerau|first3 = Carey K.|last3 = Morewedge}}</ref> People are thus more likely to choose what they observe other choosing, even if they do not believe that other person is the more knowledgeable person. People are also more likely to treat choices that require less justification as defaults. The default option for [[Parole board|parole hearings]], for example, is to deny prisoners parole.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = Extraneous factors in judicial decisions|url = http://www.pnas.org/content/108/17/6889|journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|date = 2011-04-26|issn = 0027-8424|pmc = 3084045|pmid = 21482790|pages = 6889–6892|volume = 108|issue = 17|doi = 10.1073/pnas.1018033108|language = en|first = Shai|last = Danziger|first2 = Jonathan|last2 = Levav|first3 = Liora|last3 = Avnaim-Pesso}}</ref>
== Explanations == A number of different explanations have been offered for how default setting causes a change in the choice distribution. These include Cognitive Effort, Switching Costs, Loss Aversion, Recommendation and Change of Meaning.
=== Cognitive effort === If an agent is indifferent or conflicted between options, it may involve too much cognitive effort to base a choice on explicit evaluations. In that case, he or she might disregard the evaluations and choose according to the default heuristic instead, which simply states “if there is a default, do nothing about it”.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Gigerenzer | first1 = G. | doi = 10.1111/j.1745-6916.2008.00058.x | title = Why Heuristics Work | journal = Perspectives on Psychological Science | volume = 3 | pages = 20–281 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Evidence supporting this cognitive effort account is provided in the realm of social default effects. Participants distracted by a demanding concurrent task were more likely to choose the one of two snacks that they saw a previous participant choose. Increasing the number of snacks received as a function of the choice decreased this social default effect.<ref name=":1" />
=== Switching costs === If an agent faces costs when diverging from a default that surmount the possible benefits from switching to another option, then it is rational to stick with the default option. Costs of diverging from the default might involve costs for the search of information (time, consultancy fees) and/or costs for registering the choice (time, postage, lawyer fees). This amounts to a standard [[transaction cost]] explanation from [[rational choice theory]].
=== Loss aversion === If an agent evaluates options on multiple dimensions, then the default functions as a reference point from which some dimensions are interpreted as losses and therefore becomes more important for the choice.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.2307/2937956| jstor = 2937956| title = Loss Aversion in Riskless Choice: A Reference-Dependent Model| year = 1991| last1 = Tversky | first1 = A.| last2 = Kahneman | first2 = D.| journal = The Quarterly Journal of Economics| volume = 106| issue = 4| pages = 1039}}</ref> This [[loss aversion]] explanation of the default effect can be illustrated with the following example. Let A, B and C be three different pension saving plans. The agent evaluates them (in terms of time-discounted utilities) on the two following dimensions, current consumption and future savings which obviously trade off: the more one saves for the future, the less one can consume in the present. {| class="wikitable" |- ! !! A !! B !! C |- | Consumption || 10 || 20 || 30 |- | Savings || 30 || 20 || 10
|}
Seen from plan A being the default, plans B and C constitute losses in the savings dimension. Seen from plan C being the default, however, plans A and B constitute losses in the consumption dimension. According to the theory of loss aversion, that dimension which is considered a loss influences the decision stronger than that which is considered a gain. Hence for either default A or C, the loss-averse agent would choose sticking with the default.
=== Recommendation === If an agent interprets the default as a signal from the policy maker, whom he or she sufficiently trusts, he or she might rationally decide to stick with this default. That the policy maker sets a default is interpreted as an implicit recommendation to choose that default option. The information taken from this recommendation might be sufficient to change some people's preferences.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = McKenzie | first1 = C. R. M. | last2 = Liersch | first2 = M. J. | last3 = Finkelstein | first3 = S. R. | doi = 10.1111/j.1467-9280.2006.01721.x | title = Recommendations Implicit in Policy Defaults | journal = Psychological Science | volume = 17 | issue = 5 | pages = 414–420 | year = 2006 | pmid = 16683929| pmc = }}</ref>
=== Change of meaning === Defaults also might affect the meaning of choice options and thus agents' choices over them. For example, it has been shown that under an opt-in policy in organ donation choosing not to become an organ donor is perceived as a choice of little moral failing. Under an opt-out policy, in contrast, choosing not to be an organ donor is perceived as morally more deficient.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Davidai | first1 = S. | last2 = Gilovich | first2 = T. | last3 = Ross | first3 = L. D. | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1211695109 | title = The meaning of default options for potential organ donors | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences | volume = 109 | issue = 38 | pages = 15201 | year = 2012 | pmid = 22949639| pmc = 3458339}}</ref> These differences in evaluation might affect the rational choice over these options.
== Default setting as a policy instrument == Setting or changing defaults has been proposed as an effective way of influencing behaviour—for example, with respect to deciding whether to become an organ donor,<ref name="organ"/> giving consent to receive e-mail marketing,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = E. J. | last2 = Bellman | first2 = S. | last3 = Lohse | first3 = G. L. |title=Defaults, Framing and Privacy: Why Opting In-Opting Out| journal = Marketing Letters | volume = 13 | pages = 5 | year = 2002 | doi = 10.1023/A:1015044207315 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> choosing car insurance plans,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Johnson | first1 = E. J. | last2 = Hershey | first2 = J. | last3 = Meszaros | first3 = J. | last4 = Kunreuther | first4 = H. | title = Framing, probability distortions, and insurance decisions | doi = 10.1007/BF01065313 | journal = Journal of Risk and Uncertainty | volume = 7 | pages = 35 | year = 1993 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> choosing which food to eat,<ref name=":1" /> selecting which car options to purchase,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Park | first1 = C. W. | last2 = Jun | first2 = S. Y. | last3 = MacInnis | first3 = D. J. | doi = 10.1509/jmkr.37.2.187.18731 | title = Choosing What I Want Versus Rejecting What I Do Not Want: An Application of Decision Framing to Product Option Choice Decisions | journal = Journal of Marketing Research | volume = 37 | issue = 2 | pages = 187 | year = 2000 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> choosing between different energy providers,<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Pichert | first1 = D. | last2 = Katsikopoulos | first2 = K. V. | doi = 10.1016/j.jenvp.2007.09.004 | title = Green defaults: Information presentation and pro-environmental behaviour | journal = Journal of Environmental Psychology | volume = 28 | pages = 63 | year = 2008 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> or choosing the level of one's retirement contributions.<ref>{{Cite book | last1 = Beshears | first1 = J. | last2 = Choi | first2 = J. J. | last3 = Laibson | first3 = D. | last4 = Madrian | first4 = B. C. | chapter = The Importance of Default Options for Retirement Saving Outcomes | doi = 10.7208/chicago/9780226076508.003.0006 | title = Social Security Policy in a Changing Environment | pages = 167 | year = 2009 | isbn = 978-0-226-07648-5 | pmid = | pmc = }}</ref> Setting defaults are an important example of [[nudge theory|nudges]] or [[soft paternalism|soft paternalist]] policies.

Malleable Body }} '''Doughboy''' is a fictional character appearing in [[American comic book]]s published by [[Marvel Comics]]. ==Publication history== Doughboy first appeared in ''[[Captain America (comic book)|Captain America]]'' #209 (May 1977), created by [[Jack Kirby]]. ==Fictional character biography== Doughboy is an artificially created life-form created by [[Arnim Zola]] as his servant at Castle Zola in [[Weisshorn|Weisshorn Mountain]], [[Switzerland]]. Doughboy is a non-humanoid bioform who normally assumes an enormous pie-shaped form with a face consisting of eyes, a mouth, and sometimes a nose, long rubbery arms with only two fingers each, and stalk-like legs with two toes each. His body resembles dough both in appearance and in consistency. Doughboy was employed by Arnim Zola against [[Captain America]] in Zola's first encounter with the Captain.''Captain America and the Falcon'' #209-210 Years later, Zola merged Doughboy with [[Primus (Marvel Comics)#Arnim Zola's Primus|Primus]], who took control of Doughboy and conspired with [[Baron Zemo#Baron Helmut Zemo|Baron Zemo]] against Captain America.''Captain America'' #277-279 Several years later, Doughboy was separated from Primus, and was again serving Zola. Doughboy fought and defeated [[Crossbones (comics)|Crossbones]] when they entered Zola's castle.''Captain America'' #383 Doughboy later used his shape-shifting powers to mimic an [[Avengers (comics)|Avengers]] [[quinjet]] during Zola's rescue of the [[Red Skull]] and [[Skeleton Crew (comics)|Skeleton Crew]].''Captain America'' #393 Doughboy next captured Captain America and the Eric Masterson version of [[Thunderstrike (Eric Masterson)|Thor]] at Skullhouse, and took them to the bottom of Devil's Lake on Zola's order. Doughboy was split open and smashed into bits by Masterson.''Captain America'' #395-396 Doughboy later fought the [[Thunderbolts (comics)|Thunderbolts]] when they invaded Zola's base in China.''Thunderbolts: International Incident ==Powers and abilities== Doughboy is a genetically-engineered bioform created by [[Arnim Zola]]. Doughboy is mentally impaired, but possesses a high degree of superhuman strength, durability, and agility. Doughboy possesses an extremely malleable body, enabling him to alter his shape at will. He can alter the color and even the hardness of his body, and once even effectively duplicated the appearance of an Avengers [[quinjet]].{{issue|date=April 2013}} He can stretch, deform, expand, compress, and flatten all or part of his body at will. Within certain limits he can use his body to enclose and muffle an explosion and absorb the impact of bullets or other projectiles without harm to himself. His body is highly adhesive and is as viscous as tar. Hence, his body can trap and absorb persons or objects as if it were made of quicksand. Although Doughboy can be injured, his wounds close immediately without bleeding. Doughboy can shed excess body mass at will and apparently can add to his body mass by absorption of organic matter. The [[Thunderstrike (Eric Masterson)|Eric Masterson Thor]] once battered Doughboy to pieces,{{issue|date=April 2013}} but it is believed that he was able to reform himself. Doughboy is capable of self-levitation, allowing flight and subsonic speeds. Doughboy is not sentient; hence, while he can understand and follow his master's commands, he has no creative intelligence and virtually no will of his own. He is apparently incapable of speech. ==In other media== ===Television=== * Doughboy appears in ''[[The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes]]'' episodes "Living Legend" and "Acts of Vengeance", with his vocal effects provided by [[Grant Moninger]].{{cn|date=October 2017}} * Doughboy appears in the ''[[Avengers Assemble (TV series)|Avengers Assemble]]'' episodes "The Once and Future Kang" and "Dimension Z". A giant Doughboy monster emerges from New York Harbor, where it is quickly taken down by the New Avengers and contained. Jane Foster admits she accidentally released the creature from another dimension when she attempted to locate the Avengers' whereabouts in space-time. At the time when [[Ant-Man (Scott Lang)|Ant-Man]] was rescuing Captain America, [[Black Widow (Natasha Romanova)|Black Widow]], and [[Hawkeye (comics)|Hawkeye]] from Dimension Z, one of the lines of defense in the fight against Arnim Zola was a group of Doughboys. When Ant-Man and Hawkeye managed to defeat Arnim Zola, the Doughboys dissolved. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://marvel.wikia.com/wiki/Doughboy_(Earth-616) Doughboy] at Marvel Wiki * [http://comicvine.gamespot.com/doughboy/29-27858/ Doughboy] at Comic Vine {{Captain America}} [[Category:Characters created by Jack Kirby]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1977]] [[Category:Fictional amorphous creatures]] [[Category:Fictional genetically engineered characters]] [[Category:Fictional shapeshifters]] [[Category:Marvel Comics supervillains]]

{{Expand German|Fala (Hund)|date=February 2018}} {{Infobox animal | name = Fala | image = FDR-Fala-1940-crop.jpg | image_size = 220px | caption = FDR with Fala (August 8, 1940) | birth_name = Big Boy | othername = Murray the Outlaw of Falahill (full name) | species = Dog | breed = [[Scottish Terrier]] | gender = Male | birth_date = {{Birth date|1940|04|07|mf=yes}} | birth_place = | death_date = {{BirthDeathAge||1940|04|12|1952|04|05}} | death_place = | resting_place = [[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site|Springwood]] | resting_place_coordinates = | nationality = | occupation = [[United States presidential pets|Presidential pet]] | employer = | role = | years_active = | known = | tricks = | awards = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | owner = [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] | parents = | children = | weight = | height = | appearance = | namedafter = John Murray of [[Falahill]] | website = }} '''Fala''' (April 7, 1940 – April 5, 1952), a [[Scottish Terrier]], was the [[dog]] of [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]]. One of the most famous [[List of U.S. Presidential pets|presidential pets]], Fala was taken many places by Roosevelt.[[William Edward Leuchtenburg]], ''In the Shadow of FDR: From Harry Truman to George W. Bush'', Cornell University Press, 2001, p. 183. {{ISBN|0-8014-8737-4}}. Given to the Roosevelts by a cousin, Fala knew how to perform tricks; the dog and his [[White House]] antics were mentioned frequently by the [[Media in the United States|media]] and often referenced by Roosevelt and his wife [[Eleanor Roosevelt|Eleanor]]. Fala survived Roosevelt by seven years and was buried near him. A statue of Fala beside Roosevelt is featured in [[Washington, D.C.]]'s [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial]], the only presidential pet so honored. Another statue of Fala has been placed at [[Puerto Rico]]'s "Paseo de los Presidentes" in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. ==Early life== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 260 | image1 = Fala collar.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 = Fala's silver-and-leather collar, engraved with the words "Fala, the White House". | image2 =FDR-Fala-White-House-1941-crop.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 = [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] and Fala in the White House study (December 20, 1941). }} Fala was born on April 7, 1940. Roosevelt's distant cousin, [[Margaret Suckley|Margaret "Daisy" Suckley]], gave the dog to Roosevelt as an early Christmas gift.{{Rp|200|date=June 2014}} As a puppy, Fala was given [[obedience training]] by Suckley, who taught him to sit, roll over, and jump. His original name was Big Boy; Roosevelt renamed him Murray the Outlaw of Falahill after John Murray of [[Falahill]], a famous [[Scotland|Scottish]] ancestor. This was later shortened to "Fala". After a few weeks at the White House, Fala was taken to the hospital for intestinal problems. Roosevelt discovered that Fala had found his way to the kitchen and was being overfed. Roosevelt issued an order to the staff that Fala would henceforth be fed only by the president himself.{{cite book | title=No Ordinary Time |last=Goodwin |first=Doris Kearns | authorlink = Doris Kearns Goodwin|year=1995 |publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wQcMDdFC1QEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=doris+goodwin+eleanor&hl=en&sa=X&ei=X6auUMHwNO-_2QXCx4Bo&ved=0CDoQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=doris%20goodwin%20eleanor&f=false|isbn=9780684804484|ref=harv}}{{Rp|200|date=June 2014}} ==White House years== Fala was relocated into the White House on November 10, 1940, and spent most of his time there{{cite video | year =1944 | title =Video: Allies Win Sea, Air Battle In Fight For Africa (1944) | url =https://archive.org/details/gov.archives.arc.38951 | publisher =[[Universal Newsreel]] | accessdate =February 21, 2012 }} until Roosevelt's death during April 1945. Fala also traveled with Roosevelt to his home ([[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site|Springwood]]) in [[Hyde Park, New York|Hyde Park]], [[New York (state)|New York]], and to [[Warm Springs, Georgia|Warm Springs]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], where Roosevelt received treatment for his [[Franklin D. Roosevelt's paralytic illness | paralytic illness]]. An [[MGM]] movie about a typical day in the White House featured Fala. Fala also became an honorary [[Private (rank)|private]] of the [[United States Army|U.S. Army]] by "contributing" $1 to the [[war effort]] for every day of the year and setting an example for others on the "[[home front]]". During the [[Battle of the Bulge]], American soldiers asked one another the name of the President's dog, expecting the answer "Fala," as a supplementary safeguard against German soldiers attempting to infiltrate American ranks while conducting [[Operation Grief]].Charles MacDonald, ''A Time for Trumpets: The Untold Story of the Battle of the Bulge''. New York: Harper Perennial, 1997, p. 226. {{ISBN|0-688-15157-4}} Fala often accompanied Roosevelt to important events; he traveled in ''[[Air Force One|Sacred Cow]]'', the president's airplane, and in ''[[Ferdinand Magellan Railcar|Ferdinand Magellan]]'', Roosevelt's custom-made train car, as well as by ship. He was with Roosevelt at the [[Atlantic Charter|Atlantic Charter Conference]], [[Quebec Conference, 1943|Quebec]], and the meeting with [[President of Mexico|President]] [[Manuel Ávila Camacho]] of Mexico in [[Monterrey]]. During 1943, Fala was the subject of a short series of political cartoons by Alan Foster titled ''Mr. Fala of the White House''. In the 1943 romantic comedy ''[[Princess O'Rourke]]'', Fala was played by Whiskers. ==Fala speech== On September 23, 1944, Roosevelt began his [[U.S. presidential election, 1944|1944 presidential campaign]] in Washington, D.C., speaking at a dinner with the International [[Teamsters]] Union. The half-hour speech was also broadcast by all U.S. radio networks.{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=2206&dat=19440921&id=LShVAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Xz0NAAAAIBAJ&pg=5944,5111539 |title=FDR Preparing Radio Address |publisher=''[[The Miami News]]'' ([[United Press International|United Press]]), September 21, 1944 |accessdate=2014-06-03}} In the speech, Roosevelt criticized [[United States Republican Party|Republican]] opponents in [[Congress of the United States|Congress]] and detailed their criticisms of him. Late in the speech, Roosevelt addressed Republican charges that he had accidentally left Fala behind on the [[Aleutian Islands]] while on tour there and had sent a [[United States Navy|U.S. Navy]] [[destroyer]] to retrieve him at an exorbitant cost to the taxpayers:
These Republican leaders have not been content with attacks on me, or my wife, or on my sons. No, not content with that, they now include my little dog, Fala. Well, of course, I don't resent attacks, and my family don't resent attacks, but Fala does resent them. You know, Fala is Scotch, and being a Scottie, as soon as he learned that the Republican fiction writers in Congress and out had concocted a story that I'd left him behind on an Aleutian island and had sent a destroyer back to find him—- at a cost to the taxpayers of two or three, or eight or twenty million dollars—- his Scotch soul was furious. He has not been the same dog since. I am accustomed to hearing malicious falsehoods about myself ... But I think I have a right to resent, to object, to libelous statements about my dog.{{cite web|url=https://archive.org/details/1944RadioNews |title=1944 Radio News, 1944-09-23 FDR Teamsters Union Address – Fala (27:45–30:08) |publisher=[[Internet Archive]] |accessdate=2014-06-02}}
The idea of turning the Republican charges into a joke was that of [[Orson Welles]].{{cite book |last=Leaming |first=Barbara |date=1985 |title=Orson Welles: A Biography |location=New York |publisher=[[Viking Press|Viking]] |isbn=0-670-52895-1}}{{Rp|292–293|date=June 2014}} Campaigning extensively for Roosevelt, Welles occasionally sent him ideas and phrases that were sometimes incorporated into what Welles characterized as "less important speeches".{{cite book |last=Brady |first=Frank |authorlink=Frank Brady (writer) |date=1989 |title=Citizen Welles: A Biography of Orson Welles |location=New York |publisher=[[Charles Scribner's Sons]] |isbn=0-385-26759-2}}{{Rp|374|date=February 2014}} One of these was the "Fala speech". Welles ad-libbed the Fala joke for the president, who was so delighted that he had a final version written into the speech by his staff. After the broadcast Roosevelt asked Welles, "How did I do? Was my timing right?"{{Rp|292–293|date=June 2014}} "The audience went wild, laughing and cheering and calling for more," wrote historian [[Doris Kearns Goodwin]]. "And the laughter carried beyond the banquet hall; it reverberated in living rooms and kitchens throughout the country, where people were listening to the speech on their radios. The Fala bit was so funny, one reporter observed, that 'even the stoniest of Republican faces cracked a smile.'"{{Rp|548|date=June 2014}} ==After Roosevelt's death== {{multiple image | align = right | direction = vertical | width = 260 | image1 =Eleanor Roosevelt with Fala.jpg | alt1 = | caption1 =[[Eleanor Roosevelt]] walking Fala (1947) | image2 =Eleanor Roosevelt with Fala 2.jpg | alt2 = | caption2 =Fala and Eleanor Roosevelt (1951) | image3 =Fala's Grave.jpg | alt3 = | caption3 = | image4 =Franklin Delano Roosevelt gravesite.jpg | alt4 = | caption4 =Grave near the Roosevelts at [[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site|Springwood]] }} President Roosevelt died at [[Warm Springs, Georgia]], during 1945. In the minutes after his death, Fala behaved very strangely. FDR biographer [[Jim Bishop]] wrote about the death scene: "… a snapping, snarling series of barks was heard. No one had paid any attention to Fala. He had been dozing in a corner of the room. For a reason beyond understanding, he ran directly for the front screen door and bashed his black head against it. The screen broke and he crawled through and ran snapping and barking up into the hills. There, [[United States Secret Service|Secret Service]] men could see him, standing alone, unmoving, on an eminence. This led to the quiet question: 'Do dogs really know?'" [[Jim Bishop|Bishop, Jim]], ''FDR's Last Year''. New York: William Morrow, 1974, pp. 590–591. Fala attended Roosevelt's funeral{{Rp|615|date=June 2014}} and went to live with the widowed [[Eleanor Roosevelt]] at [[Eleanor Roosevelt National Historic Site|Val-Kill]].{{Rp|620|date=June 2014}} She took great pleasure in Fala's company, and the two became inseparable companions.{{Rp|620|date=June 2014}} She often mentioned Fala in her newspaper column, "My Day", and wrote of him in her autobiography:
It was Fala, my husband's little dog, who never really readjusted. Once, in 1945, when General Eisenhower came to lay a wreath on Franklin's grave, the gates of the regular driveway were opened and his automobile approached the house accompanied by the wailing of the sirens of a police escort. When Fala heard the sirens, his legs straightened out, his ears pricked up and I knew that he expected to see his master coming down the drive as he had come so many times. Later, when we were living in the cottage, Fala always lay near the dining-room door where he could watch both entrances just as he did when his master was there. Franklin would often decide suddenly to go somewhere and Fala had to watch both entrances in order to be ready to spring up and join the party on short notice. Fala accepted me after my husband's death, but I was just someone to put up with until the master should return.Roosevelt, Eleanor, ''The Autobiography of Eleanor Roosevelt''. New York: Da Capo Press, 1992{{Rp|287–288|date=June 2014}}
During November 1945 Fala was hospitalized for a week after being attacked at the family's Hyde Park estate by [[Elliott Roosevelt]]'s 135-pound [[bull mastiff]], Blaze.{{cite news |author= |title=Fala In Hospital After Run In With Bulldog |url= |newspaper=[[The Herald-Mail|The Daily Mail]] ''([[Associated Press]])'' |location= |date=November 29, 1945 |access-date= }} Fala had been staying with Margaret Suckley and visited Hyde Park. He was on a leash when the larger dog jumped on him, slashing his back and right eye. The attack ended when someone struck Blaze with a rock and dazed him. Blaze tested negative for rabies, but was still euthanized as a precaution against future attacks.{{cite news |author= |title=Elliott's Blaze Destroyed for Attack on Fala |url= |newspaper=[[The Daily Register]] ''([[United Press International|United Press]])'' |location= |date=November 30, 1945 |access-date= }} Suffering from deafness and failing health, Fala was euthanized on April 5, 1952, two days before his twelfth birthday.{{cite news|title=Fala Buried in Hyde Park Garden At Feet of Friend and Champion|url=http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1952/04/07/93364315.html?pageNumber=27|accessdate=9 May 2015|work=The New York Times|date=7 April 1952|page=27|quote=Fala received a 'mercy death' two days before his thirteenth [sic] birthday. He had been in failing health for some time. His hair had turned gray and he suffered from deafness.}} Fala is buried in a marked grave about ten yards behind the Roosevelt tombstone in the Rose Garden at [[Home of Franklin D. Roosevelt National Historic Site|Springwood]],{{cite web |url=http://www.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/education/resources/bio_fala.html |title=Biography of Fala D. Roosevelt |publisher=Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library |accessdate=7 December 2012 |archivedate=7 December 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CjiiJ4bQ?url=http://www.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/education/resources/bio_fala.html |deadurl=no |df= }} beside Chief (1918–1933), the Roosevelts' [[German Shepherd]].{{cite web |url=http://www.fdrlibrary.marist.edu/facts/ |title=Roosevelt Facts and Figures |publisher=[[Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum]] |access-date=2015-09-24}} ==Memorials== A statue of Fala beside Roosevelt is featured in the [[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial]] in Washington, D.C. Fala is the only presidential pet so honored. Another statue of him has been placed at [[Puerto Rico]]'s "Paseo de los Presidentes" in [[San Juan, Puerto Rico|San Juan]]. A third statue is in the Franklin Delano Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum in Hyde Park, NY. Fala's collar, dog dish, White House dog tags and other artifacts also are on display. {{citation needed|date=June 2014}} File:FDR-Memorial-Fala.jpg|[[Franklin Delano Roosevelt Memorial]]

[[Disney family|Ruth Flora Disney]] }} '''Flora Call Disney''' (April 22, 1868{{spaced ndash}}November 26, 1938) was the mother of [[Walt Disney|Walt]] and [[Roy O. Disney|Roy Disney]]. ==Family== Call was born in [[Steuben, Ohio]], the daughter of Henrietta (née Gross; 1837–1910) and Charles Call (1823–1890), who were neighbors of Kepple Disney, father of [[Elias Disney]], her husband. She was of [[Germany|German]] and English descent.{{cite web|url=http://www.wargs.com/political/cheney.html|title=Ancestry of Dick Cheney (b. 1941)|work=wargs.com}} ==Death== Flora died in 1938 in an accident that plagued her son Walt with grief for the rest of his life.{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lSJIngvkCsAC&lpg=PP1&pg=PA131#v=onepage&q&f=false | title=How to Be Like Walt: Capturing the Disney Magic Every Day of Your Life | publisher=HCI | author=Williams, Pat | year=2004 | pages=131}} After the success of their film ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', in 1938, Walt and Roy presented their parents with a new home in [[North Hollywood]], near the Disney studios in [[Burbank, California]]. Less than a month after moving in, Flora complained to Walt and Roy of problems with the gas furnace in her new home. Studio repairmen were sent to the house, but the problem was not adequately fixed.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} Flora wrote a letter to her daughter Ruth describing the wonderful new home, but again complaining of the fumes from the furnace. A few days later, Flora died of [[asphyxiation]] caused by the fumes at age 70.{{citation needed|date=July 2013}} She is entombed next to her husband in Glendale's [[Forest Lawn Memorial Park, Glendale|Forest Lawn Memorial Park Cemetery]]. ==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[Roles of mothers in Disney media|Disney Mothers]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{Find a Grave|8807}} *{{IMDb name|1089523|Flora Call Disney}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060106000050/http://www.teachersparadise.com/ency/en/wikipedia/f/fl/flora_call.html teacherparadise.com information] *[http://disney.go.com/disneyatoz/familymuseum/collection/biography/marceline/ Walt's Biography] *[http://www.answers.com/topic/flora-call-disney Flora Disney at Answers.com] {{DEFAULTSORT:Disney, Flora Call}} [[Category:1868 births]] [[Category:1938 deaths]] [[Category:American people of English descent]] [[Category:American people of German descent]] [[Category:Accidental deaths in California]] [[Category:Deaths from asphyxiation]] [[Category:People from Huron County, Ohio]] [[Category:Burials at Forest Lawn Memorial Park (Glendale)]] [[Category:Disney family|Flora Call]]

{{Infobox person | name = Frederick Stark Pearson | image = CAB 1918 Pearson Frederick Stark.jpg | caption = Frederick Stark Pearson | birth_name = | birth_date = {{Birth date|1861|7|3}} | birth_place = [[Lowell, Massachusetts]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|1915|5|7|1861|7|3}} | death_place = {{RMS|Lusitania}}, [[Atlantic Ocean]] | other_names = | occupation = Electrical Engineer, Entrepreneur | years_active = | spouse = Mabel Ward Pearson | children = | signature = CAB 1918 Pearson Frederick Stark signature.png }}
'''Frederick Stark Pearson''' (July 3, 1861 – May 7, 1915) was an [[United States|American]] [[electrical engineer]] and [[entrepreneur]].
==Biography== Dr. Frederick Stark Pearson was the son of Ambrose and Hannah (Edgerly) Pearson. He graduated from [[Tufts University]] in 1883 with an A.M.B. and received an A.M.M. degree one year later. Previously, for one year (1879–80), he was instructor in [[chemistry]] in the [[Massachusetts Institute of Technology]]; later (1883–86), he was instructor in mathematics and applied mechanics at Tufts College. From college, he went on to develop the electric transportation system in [[Boston]] and, with electric powered streetcars of major importance, in 1894 he was appointed the head engineer for Metropolitan Street Railways in [[New York City]]. Pearson built a reputation as an innovative electrical engineer in the United States and he was soon contracted by governments and businesses as a consulting engineer for power generating stations throughout [[North America]]. A man with great business skills and a foresight, with ready financial backers he undertook major projects in [[North America|North]] and [[South America]]. He was the Founder of [[Barcelona Traction]] and [[Brookfield Asset Management]].
While in Canada, he developed a relationship with a bright and aggressive young lawyer/stockbroker in [[Montreal, Quebec]] by the name of [[Sir James Dunn|James Dunn]]. Pearson encouraged Dunn to take up residency in [[London]], at the time the most important financial market in the world.
With Dunn's brokerage house underwriting his ventures share offerings, sufficient capital was raised to allow Pearson to create a massive business empire that included the [[São Paulo Tramway, Light and Power Company]] in [[Brazil]], the Mexican North Western Railway, the Mexican Tramway Company, and the [[Mexican Light and Power Company]] in [[Mexico]], and the [[British American Nickel Company]] in Canada.
Unstable governments in Mexico along with rampant bribery and corruption of public officials caused Pearson considerable grief. The government of president [[Venustiano Carranza]] nationalized his Mexican Tramway Company and in the end, he lost virtually everything he had invested in Mexico. During this time, he was behind the 1911 construction of the [[Medina Dam]] on the [[Medina River]] in what is now [[Mico, Texas]] and built an irrigation district encompassing more than 34,000 acres (138 km²). The town of [[Pearson, Texas]] was named in his honor.
In 1912, he organized a syndicate in [[Hale County, Texas]] near [[Plainview, Texas|Plainview]] for drilling irrigation wells to irrigate about 60,000 acres (243 km²). During the course of his work in Texas, Pearson founded the town of [[Natalia, Texas|Natalia]], naming it after his daughter, Natalie Pearson Nicholson.
In 1913, he negotiated a deal with the [[Spain|Spanish]] government for a hydro project on the [[Ebro River]] and formed the [[Barcelona Traction]], Light and Power Company to carry out the construction that was completed in 1915. However, [[World War I]] limited his activity.
He and his wife, Mabel Ward Pearson, lost their lives on May 7, 1915, while travelling to England on business and to visit his daughter Natalie who was then living there. They were on the ocean liner {{RMS|Lusitania}} when it was torpedoed off the southern coast of [[Ireland]] by German [[U-boat]] {{SMU|U-20|Germany|2}}.
Pearson Hall, home of the Chemistry Department at Tufts University, is named for him.
